Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:102
verses.text: The same to the Controller, and to Philagrius, at that time Prefect of Egypt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:103
verses.text: To Flavius Philagrius, and to Flavius Palladius, Ducenary, Officer of the Palace, and Controller, and to Flavius Antoninus, Commissary of Provisions, and Centenary of my lords the most illustrious Prefects of the sacred Praetorium, these from the Presbyters and Deacons of the Mareotis, a nome of the Catholic Church which is under the most Reverend Bishop Athanasius, we address this testimony by those whose names are underwritten:â€”  Whereas Theognius, Maris, Macedonius, Theodorus, Ursacius, and Valens, as if sent by all the Bishops who assembled at Tyre, came into our Diocese alleging that they had received orders to investigate certain ecclesiastical affairs, among which they spoke of the breaking of a cup of the Lord, of which information was given them by Ischyras, whom they brought with them, and who says that he is a Presbyter, although he is not,â€”for he was ordained by the Presbyter Colluthus who pretended to the Episcopate, and was afterwards ordered by a whole Council, by Hosius and the Bishops that were with him, to take the place of a Presbyter, as he was before; and accordingly all that were ordained by Colluthus resumed the same rank which they held before, and so Ischyras himself proved to be a layman,â€”and the church which he says he has, never was a church at all, but a quite small private house belonging to an orphan boy of the name of Ision;â€”for this reason we have offered this testimony, adjuring you by Almighty God, and by our Lords Constantine Augustus, and the most illustrious Caesars his sons, to bring these things to the knowledge of their piety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:104
verses.text: For neither is he a Presbyter of the Catholic Church nor does he possess a church, nor has a cup ever been broken, but the whole story is false and an invention.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:105
verses.text: Dated in the Consulship of Julius Constantius the most illustrious Patrician, brother of the most religious Emperor Constantine Augustus, and of Rufinus Albinus, most illustrious men, on the tenth day of the month Thoth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:106
verses.text: These were the letters of the Presbyters.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:107
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:108
verses.text: The following also are the letters and protests of the Bishops who came with us to Tyre, when they became aware of the conspiracy and plot.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:109
verses.text: To the Bishops assembled at Tyre, most honoured Lords, those of the Catholic Church who have come from Egypt with Athanasius send greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:110
verses.text: We suppose that the conspiracy which has been formed against us by Eusebius, Theognius, Maris, Narcissus, Theodorus, Patrophilus, and their fellows is no longer uncertain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:111
verses.text: From the very beginning we all demurred, through our fellow-minister Athanasius, to the holding of the enquiry in their presence, knowing that the presence of even one enemy only, much more of many, is able to disturb and injure the hearing of a cause.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:112
verses.text: And you also yourselves know the enmity which they entertain, not only towards us, but towards all the orthodox, how that for the sake of the madness of Arius, and his impious doctrine, they direct their assaults, they form conspiracies against all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:113
verses.text: And when, being confident in the truth, we desired to shew the falsehood, which the Meletians had employed against the Church, Eusebius and his fellows endeavoured by some means or other to interrupt our representations, and strove eagerly to set aside our testimony, threatening those who gave an honest judgment, and insulting others, for the sole purpose of carrying out the design they had against us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:114
verses.text: Your godly piety, most honoured Lords, was probably ignorant of their conspiracy, but we suppose that it has now been made manifest.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:115
verses.text: For indeed they have themselves plainly disclosed it; for they desired to send to the Mareotis those of their party who are suspected by us, so that, while we were absent and remained here, they might disturb the people and accomplish what they wished.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:116
verses.text: They knew that the Arian madmen, and Colluthians and Meletians, were enemies of the Catholic Church and therefore they were anxious to send them, that in the presence of our enemies they might devise against us whatever schemes they pleased.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:117
verses.text: And those of the Meletians who are here, even four days previously (as they knew that this enquiry was about to take place), despatched at evening certain of their party, as couriers, for the purpose of collecting Meletians out of Egypt into the Mareotis, because there were none at all there, and Colluthians and Arian madmen, from other parts, and to prepare them to speak against us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:118
verses.text: For you also know that Ischyras himself confessed before you, that he had not more than seven persons in his congregation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:119
verses.text: When therefore we heard that, after they had made what preparations they pleased against us, and had sent these suspected persons, they were going about to each of you, and requiring your subscriptions, in order that it might appear as if this had been done with the consent of you all; for this reason we hastened to write to you, and to present this our testimony; declaring that we are the objects of a conspiracy under which we are suffering by and through them, and demanding that having the fear of God in your minds, and condemning their conduct in sending whom they pleased without our consent, you would refuse your subscriptions, lest they pretend that those things are done by you, which they are contriving only among themselves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:120
verses.text: Surely it becomes those who are in Christ, not to regard human motives, but to prefer the truth before all things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:121
verses.text: And be not afraid of their threatenings, which they employ against all, nor of their plots, but rather fear God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:122
verses.text: If it was at all necessary that persons should be sent to the Mareotis, we also ought to have been there with them, in order that we might convict the enemies of the Church, and point out those who were aliens, and that the investigation of the matter might be impartial.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:123
verses.text: For you know that Eusebius and his fellows contrived that a letter should be presented, as coming from the Collutians, the Meletians, and Arians, and directed against us: but it is evident that these enemies of the Catholic Church speak nothing that is true concerning us, but say everything against us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:124
verses.text: And the law of God forbids an enemy to be either a witness or a judge.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:125
verses.text: Wherefore as you will have to give an account in the day of judgment, receive this testimony, and recognising the conspiracy which has been framed against us, beware, if you are requested by them, of doing anything against us, and of taking part in the designs of Eusebius and his fellows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:126
verses.text: For you know, as we said before, that they are our enemies, and you are aware why Eusebius of Caesarea became such last year.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:127
verses.text: We pray that you may be in health, greatly beloved Lords.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:128
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:129
verses.text: To the most illustrious Count Flavius Dionysius, from the Bishops of the Catholic Church in Egypt who have come to Tyre.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:130
verses.text: We suppose that the conspiracy which has been formed against us by Eusebius, Theognius, Maris, Narcissus, Theodorus, Patrophilus and their fellows, is no longer uncertain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:131
verses.text: From the very beginning we all demurred, through our fellow-minister Athanasius, to the holding of the enquiry in their presence, knowing that the presence of even one enemy only, much more of many, is able to disturb and injure the hearing of a cause.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:132
verses.text: For their enmity is manifest which they entertain, not only towards us, but also towards all the orthodox, because they direct their assaults, they form conspiracies against all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:133
verses.text: And when, being confident in the truth, we desired to shew the falsehood which the Meletians had employed against the Church, Eusebius and his fellows endeavoured by some means or other to interrupt our representations, and strove eagerly to set aside our testimony, threatening those who gave an honest judgment and insulting others, for the sole purpose of carrying out the design they had against us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:134
verses.text: Your goodness was probably ignorant of the conspiracy which they have formed against us, but we suppose that it has now been made manifest.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:135
verses.text: For indeed they have themselves plainly disclosed it; for they desired to send to the Mareotis those of their party who are suspected by us, so that, while we were absent and remained here, they might disturb the people and accomplish what they wished.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:136
verses.text: They knew that Arian madmen, Colluthians, and Meletians were enemies of the Church, and therefore they were anxious to send them, that in the presence of our enemies, they might devise against us whatever schemes they pleased.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:137
verses.text: And those of the Meletians who are here, even four days previously (as they knew that this enquiry was about to take place), despatched at evening two individuals of their own party, as couriers, for the purpose of collecting Meletians out of Egypt into the Mareotis, because there were none at all there, and Colluthians, and Arian madmen, from other parts, and to prepare them to speak against us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:138
verses.text: And your goodness knows that he himself confessed before you, that he had not more than seven persons in his congregation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:139
verses.text: When therefore we heard that, after they had made what preparations they pleased against us, and had sent these suspected persons, they were going about to each of the Bishops and requiring their subscriptions, in order that it might appear that this was done with the consent of them all; for this reason we hastened to refer the matter to your honour, and to present this our testimony, declaring that we are the objects of a conspiracy, under which we are suffering by and through them, and demanding of you that having in your mind the fear of God, and the pious commands of our most religious Emperor, you would no longer tolerate these persons, but condemn their conduct in sending whom they pleased without our consent.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:140
verses.text: I Adamantius Bishop have subscribed this letter, Ischyras, Ammon, Peter, Ammonianus, Tyrannus, Taurinus, Sarapammon, aelurion, Harpocration, Moses, Optatus, Anubion, Saprion, Apollonius, Ischyrion, Arbaethion, Potamon, Paphnutius, Heraclides, Theodorus, Agathammon, Gaius, Pistus, Athas, Nicon, Pelagius, Theon, Paninuthius, Nonnus, Ariston, Theodorus, Irenaeus, Blastammon, Philippus, Apollos, Dioscorus, Timotheus of Diospolis, Macarius, Heraclammon, Cronius, Myis, Jacobus, Ariston, Artemidorus, Phinees, Psais, Heraclides.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:141
verses.text: Another from the same.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:142
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:143
verses.text: The Bishops of the Catholic Church who have come from Egypt to Tyre, to the most illustrious Count Flavius Dionysius.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:144
verses.text: Perceiving that many conspiracies and plots are being formed against us through the machinations of Eusebius, Narcissus, Flacillus, Theognius, Maris, Theodorus, Patrophilus, and their fellows (against whom we wished at first to enter an objection, but were not permitted), we are constrained to have recourse to the present appeal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:145
verses.text: We observe also that great zeal is exerted in behalf of the Meletians, and that a plot is laid against the Catholic Church in Egypt in our persons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:146
verses.text: Wherefore we present this letter to you, beseeching you to bear in mind the Almighty Power of God, who defends the kingdom of our most religious and godly Emperor Constantine, and to reserve the hearing of the affairs which concern us for the most religious Emperor himself.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:147
verses.text: For it is but reasonable, since you were commissioned by his Majesty, that you should reserve the matter for him upon our appealing to his piety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:148
verses.text: We can no longer endure to be the objects of the treacherous designs of the fore-mentioned Eusebius and his fellows, and therefore we demand that the case be reserved for the most religious and God-beloved Emperor, before whom we shall be able to set forth our own and the Church's just claims.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:149
verses.text: And we are convinced that when his piety shall have heard our cause, he will not condemn us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:150
verses.text: Wherefore we again adjure you by Almighty God, and by our most religious Emperor, who, together with the children of his piety, has thus ever been victorious and prosperous these many years, that you proceed no further, nor suffer yourselves to move at all in the Council in relation to our affairs, but reserve the hearing of them for his piety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:151
verses.text: We have likewise made the same representations to my Lords the orthodox Bishops.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:152
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:153
verses.text: Alexander, Bishop of Thessalonica, on receiving these letters, wrote to the Count Dionysius as follows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:154
verses.text: The Bishop Alexander to my master Dionysius.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:155
verses.text: I see that a conspiracy has evidently been formed against Athanasius; for they have determined, I know not on what grounds, to send all those to whom he has objected, without giving any information to us, although it was agreed that we should consider together who ought to be sent.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:156
verses.text: Take care therefore that nothing be done rashly (for they have come to me in great alarm, saying that the wild beasts have already roused themselves, and are going to rush upon them; for they had heard it reported, that John had sent certain), lest they be beforehand with us, and concoct what schemes they please.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:157
verses.text: For you know that the Colluthians who are enemies of the Church, and the Arians, and Meletians, are all of them leagued together, and are able to work much evil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:158
verses.text: Consider therefore what is best to be done, lest some mischief arise, and we be subject to censure, as not having judged the matter fairly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:159
verses.text: Great suspicions are also entertained of these persons, lest, as being devoted to the Meletians, they should go through those Churches whose Bishops are here, and raise an alarm amongst them, and so disorder the whole of Egypt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:160
verses.text: For they see that this is already taking place to a great extent.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:161
verses.text: Accordingly the Count Dionysius wrote to Eusebius and his fellows as follows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:162
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:163
verses.text: This is what I have already mentioned to my lords, Flacillus and his fellows, that Athanasius has come forward and complained that those very persons have been sent whom he objected to; and crying out that he has been wronged and deceived.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:164
verses.text: Alexander the lord of my soul has also written to me on the subject; and that you may perceive that what his Goodness has said is reasonable, I have subjoined his letter to be read by you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:165
verses.text: Remember also what I wrote to you before: I impressed upon your Goodness, my lords, that the persons who were sent ought to be commissioned by the general vote and decision of all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:166
verses.text: Take care therefore lest our proceedings fall under censure, and we give just grounds of blame to those who are disposed to find fault with us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:167
verses.text: For as the accuser's side ought not to suffer any oppression, so neither ought the defendant's.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:168
verses.text: And I think that there is no slight ground of blame against us, when my lord Alexander evidently disapproves of what we have done.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:169
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:170
verses.text: While matters were proceeding thus we withdrew from them, as from an assembly of treacherous men, for whatsoever they pleased they did, whereas there is no man in the world but knows that ex parte proceedings cannot stand good.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:171
verses.text: This the divine law determines; for when the blessed Apostle was suffering under a similar conspiracy and was brought to trial, he demanded, saying, 'The Jews from Asia ought to have been here before thee, and object, if they had aught against me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:172
verses.text: ' On which occasion Festus also, when the Jews wished to lay such a plot against him, as these men have now laid against me, said, 'It is not the manner of Romans to deliver any man to die, before that he which is accused have the accuser face to face, and have licence to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:173
verses.text: ' But Eusebius and his fellows both had the boldness to pervert the law, and have proved more unjust even than those wrong-doers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:174
verses.text: For they did not proceed privately at the first, but when in consequence of our being present they found themselves weak, then they straightway went out, like the Jews, and took counsel together alone, how they might destroy us and bring in their heresy, as those others demanded Barabbas.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:175
verses.text: For this purpose it was, as they have themselves confessed, that they did all these things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:176
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:177
verses.text: Although these circumstances were amply sufficient for our vindication, yet in order that the wickedness of these men and the freedom of the truth might be more fully exhibited, I have not felt averse to repeat them again, in order to shew that they have acted in a manner inconsistently with themselves, and as men scheming in the dark have fallen foul of their own friends, and while they desired to destroy us have like insane persons wounded themselves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:178
verses.text: For in their investigation of the subject of the Mysteries, they questioned Jews, they examined Catechumens; 'Where were you,' they said, 'when Macarius came and overturned the Table?' They answered, 'We were within;' whereas there could be no oblation if Catechumens were present.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:179
verses.text: Again, although they had written word everywhere, that Macarius came and overthrew everything, while the Presbyter was standing and celebrating the Mysteries, yet when they questioned whomsoever they pleased, and asked them, 'Where was Ischyras when Macarius rushed in?' those persons answered that he was lying sick in a cell.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:180
verses.text: Well, then, he that was lying was not standing, nor was he that lay sick in his cell offering the oblation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:181
verses.text: Besides whereas Ischyras said that certain books had been burnt by Macarius, they who were suborned to give evidence, declared that nothing of the kind had been done, but that Ischyras spoke falsely.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:182
verses.text: And what is most remarkable, although they had again written word everywhere, that those who were able to give evidence had been concealed by us, yet these persons made their appearance, and they questioned them, and were not ashamed when they saw it proved on all sides that they were slanderers, and were acting in this matter clandestinely, and according to their pleasure.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:183
verses.text: For they prompted the witnesses by signs, while the Prefect threatened them, and the soldiers pricked them with their swords; but the Lord revealed the truth, and shewed them to be slanderers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:184
verses.text: Therefore also they concealed the minutes of their proceedings, which they retained themselves, and charged those who wrote them to put out of sight, and to commit to no one whomsoever.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:185
verses.text: But in this also they were disappointed; for the person who wrote them was Rufus, who is now public executioner in the Augustalian prefecture, and is able to testify to the truth of this; and Eusebius and his fellows sent them to Rome by the hands of their own friends, and Julius the Bishop transmitted them to me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:186
verses.text: And now they are mad, because we obtained and read what they wished to conceal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:187
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:188
verses.text: As such was the character of their machinations, so they very soon shewed plainly the reasons of their conduct.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:189
verses.text: For when they went away, they took the Arians with them to Jerusalem, and there admitted them to communion, having sent out a letter concerning them, part of which, and the beginning, is as follows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:190
verses.text: The holy Council by the grace of God assembled at Jerusalem, to the Church of God which is in Alexandria, and to the Bishops, Presbyters, and Deacons, in all Egypt, the Thebais, Libya, Pentapolis, and throughout the world, sends health in the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:191
verses.text: Having come together out of different Provinces to a great meeting which we have held for the consecration of the Martyry of the Saviour, which has been appointed to the service of God the King of all and of His Christ, by the zeal of our most God-beloved Emperor Constantine, the grace of God hath afforded us more abundant rejoicing of heart; which our most God-beloved Emperor himself hath occasioned us by his letters, wherein he hath stirred us up to do that which is right, putting away all envy from the Church of God, and driving far from us all malice, by which the members of God have been heretofore torn asunder, and that we should with simple and peaceable minds receive Arius and his fellows, whom envy, that enemy of all goodness, has caused for a season to be excluded from the Church.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:192
verses.text: Our most religious Emperor has also in his letter testified to the correctness of their faith, which he has ascertained from themselves, himself receiving the profession of it from them by word of mouth, and has now made manifest to us by subjoining to his own letters the men's orthodox opinion in writing.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:193
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:194
verses.text: Every one that hears of these things must see through their treachery.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:195
verses.text: For they made no concealment of what they were doing; unless perhaps they confessed the truth without wishing it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:196
verses.text: For if I was the hindrance to the admittance of Arius and his fellows into the Church, and if they were received while I was suffering from their plots, what other conclusion can be arrived at, than that these things were done on their account, and that all their proceedings against me, and the story which they fabricated about the breaking of the cup and the murder of Arsenius, were for the sole purpose of introducing impiety into the Church, and of preventing their being condemned as heretics? For this was what the Emperor threatened formerly in his letters to me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:197
verses.text: And they were not ashamed to write in the manner they did, and to affirm that those persons whom the whole Ecumenical Council anathematized held orthodox sentiments.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:198
verses.text: And as they undertook to say and do anything without scruple, so they were not afraid to meet together 'in a corner,' in order to overthrow, as far as was in their power, the authority of so great a Council.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:199
verses.text: Moreover, the price which they paid for false testimony yet more fully manifests their wickedness and impious intentions.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:200
verses.text: The Mareotis, as I have already said, is a country district of Alexandria, in which there has never been either a Bishop or a Chorepiscopus; but the Churches of the whole district are subject to the Bishop of Alexandria, and each Presbyter has under his charge one of the largest villages, which are about ten or more in number.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:201
verses.text: Now the village in which Ischyras lives is a very small one, and possesses so few inhabitants, that there has never been a church built there, but only in the adjoining village.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:202
verses.text: Nevertheless, they determined, contrary to ancient usage, to nominate a Bishop for this place, and not only so, but even to appoint one, who was not so much as a Presbyter.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:203
verses.text: Knowing as they did the unusual nature of such a proceeding, yet being constrained by the promises they had given in return for his false impeachment of me, they submitted even to this, lest that abandoned person, if he were ungratefully treated by them, should disclose the truth, and thereby shew the wickedness of Eusebius and his fellows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:204
verses.text: Notwithstanding this he has no church, nor a people to obey him, but is scouted by them all, like a dog, although they have even caused the Emperor to write to the Receiver-General (for everything is in their power), commanding that a church should be built for him, that being possessed of that, his statement may appear credible about the cup and the table.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:205
verses.text: They caused him immediately to be nominated a Bishop also, because if he were without a church, and not even a Presbyter, he would appear to be a false accuser, and a fabricator of the whole matter.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:206
verses.text: At any rate he has no people, and even his own relations are not obedient to him, and as the name which he retains is an empty one, so also the following letter is ineffectual, which he keeps, making a display of it as an exposure of the utter wickedness of himself and of Eusebius and his fellows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:207
verses.text: The Letter of the Receiver-General.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:208
verses.text: Flavius Hemerius sends health to the Tax-collector of the Mareotis.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:209
verses.text: Ischyras the Presbyter having petitioned the piety of our Lords, Augusti and Caesars, that a Church might be built in the district of Irene, belonging to Secontarurus, their divinity has commanded that this should be done as soon as possible.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:210
verses.text: Take care therefore, as soon as you receive the copy of the sacred Edict, which with all due veneration is placed above, and the Reports which have been formed before my devotion, that you quickly make an abstract of them, and transfer them to the Order book, so that the sacred command may be put in execution.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:211
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:212
verses.text: While they were thus plotting and scheming, I went up and represented to the Emperor the unjust conduct of Eusebius and his fellows, for he it was who had commanded the Council to be held, and his Count presided at it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:213
verses.text: When he heard my report, he was greatly moved, and wrote to them as follows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:214
verses.text: Constantine, Victor, Maximus, Augustus, to the Bishops assembled at Tyre.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:215
verses.text: I know not what the decisions are which you have arrived at in your Council amidst noise and tumult: but somehow the truth seems to have been perverted in consequence of certain confusions and disorders, in that you, through your mutual contentiousness, which you are resolved should prevail, have failed to perceive what is pleasing to God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:216
verses.text: However, it will rest with Divine Providence to disperse the mischiefs which manifestly are found to arise from this contentious spirit, and to shew plainly to us, whether you, while assembled in that place, have had any regard for the truth, and whether you have made your decisions uninfluenced by either favour or enmity.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:217
verses.text: Wherefore I wish you all to assemble with all speed before my piety in order that you may render in person a true account of your proceedings.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:218
verses.text: The reason why I have thought good to write thus to you, and why I summon you before me by letter, you will learn from what I am going to say.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:219
verses.text: As I was entering on a late occasion our all-happy home of Constantinople, which bears our name (I chanced at the time to be on horseback), on a sudden the Bishop Athanasius, with certain others whom he had with him, approached me in the middle of the road, so unexpectedly, as to occasion me much amazement.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:220
verses.text: God, who knoweth all things, is my witness, that I should have been unable at first sight even to recognise him, had not some of my attendants, on my naturally inquiring of them, informed me both who it was, and under what injustice he was suffering.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:221
verses.text: I did not however enter into any conversation with him at that time, nor grant him an interview; but when he requested to be heard I was refusing, and all but gave orders for his removal; when with increasing boldness he claimed only this favour, that you should be summoned to appear, that he might have an opportunity of complaining before me in your presence, of the ill-treatment he has met with.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:222
verses.text: As this appeared to me to be a reasonable request, and suitable to the times, I willingly ordered this letter to be written to you, in order that all of you, who constituted the Council which was held at Tyre, might hasten without delay to the Court of my clemency, so as to prove by facts that you had passed an impartial and uncorrupt judgment.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:223
verses.text: This, I say, you must do before me, whom not even you will deny to be a true servant of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:224
verses.text: For indeed through my devotion to God, peace is preserved everywhere, and the Name of God is truly worshipped even by the barbarians, who have hitherto been ignorant of the truth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:225
verses.text: And it is manifest, that he who is ignorant of the truth, does not know God either.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:226
verses.text: Nevertheless, as I said before, even the barbarians have now come to the knowledge of God, by means of me, His true servant, and have learned to fear Him Whom they perceive from actual facts to be my shield and protector everywhere.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:227
verses.text: And from this chiefly they have come to know God, Whom they fear through the dread which they have of me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:228
verses.text: But we, who are supposed to set forth (for I will not say to guard) the holy mysteries of His Goodness, we, I say, engage in nothing but what tends to dissension and hatred, and, in short, whatever contributes to the destruction of mankind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:229
verses.text: But hasten, as I said before, and all of you with all speed come to us, being persuaded that I shall endeavour with all my might to amend what is amiss, so that those things specially may be preserved and firmly established in the law of God, to which no blame nor dishonour may attach; while the enemies of the law, who under pretence of His holy Name bring in manifold and divers blasphemies, shall be scattered abroad, and entirely crushed, and utterly destroyed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:230
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:231
verses.text: When Eusebius and his fellows read this letter, being conscious of what they had done, they prevented the rest of the Bishops from going up, and only themselves went, viz.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:232
verses.text: Eusebius, Theognius, Patrophilus, the other Eusebius, Ursacius, and Valens.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:233
verses.text: And they no longer said anything about the cup and Arsenius (for they had not the boldness to do so), but inventing another accusation which concerned the Emperor himself, they declared before him, that Athanasius had threatened that he would cause the corn to be withheld which was sent from Alexandria to his own home.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:234
verses.text: The Bishops Adamantius, Anubion, Agathammon, Arbethion, and Peter, were present and heard this.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:235
verses.text: It was proved also by the anger of the Emperor; for although he had written the preceding letter, and had condemned their injustice, as soon as he heard such a charge as this, he was immediately incensed, and instead of granting me a hearing, he sent me away into Gaul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:236
verses.text: And this again shews their wickedness further; for when the younger Constantine, of blessed memory, sent me back home, remembering what his father had written, he also wrote as follows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:237
verses.text: Constantine Caesar, to the people of the Catholic Church of the city of Alexandria.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:238
verses.text: I suppose that it has not escaped the knowledge of your pious minds, that Athanasius, the interpreter of the adorable Law, was sent away into Gaul for a time, with the intent that, as the savageness of his bloodthirsty and inveterate enemies persecuted him to the hazard of his sacred life, he might thus escape suffering some irremediable calamity, through the perverse dealing of those evil men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:239
verses.text: In order therefore to escape this, he was snatched out of the jaws of his assailants, and was ordered to pass some time under my government, and so was supplied abundantly with all necessaries in this city, where he lived, although indeed his celebrated virtue, relying entirely on divine assistance, sets at nought the sufferings of adverse fortune.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:240
verses.text: Now seeing that it was the fixed intention of our master Constantine Augustus, my Father, to restore the said Bishop to his own place, and to your most beloved piety, but he was taken away by that fate which is common to all men, and went to his rest before he could accomplish his wish; I have thought proper to fulfil that intention of the Emperor of sacred memory which I have inherited from him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:241
verses.text: When he comes to present himself before you, you will learn with what reverence he has been treated.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:242
verses.text: Indeed it is not wonderful, whatever I have done on his behalf; for the thoughts of your longing desire for him, and the appearance of so great a man, moved my soul, and urged me thereto.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:243
verses.text: May Divine Providence continually preserve you, beloved brethren.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:244
verses.text: Dated from Treveri the 15th before the Calends of July.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:245
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:246
verses.text: This being the reason why I was sent away into Gaul, who, I ask again, does not plainly perceive the intention of the Emperor, and the murderous spirit of Eusebius and his fellows, and that the Emperor had done this in order to prevent their forming some more desperate scheme? for he listened to them in simplicity.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:247
verses.text: Such were the practices of Eusebius and his fellows, and such their machinations against me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:248
verses.text: Who that has witnessed them will deny that nothing has been done in my favour out of partiality, but that that great number of Bishops both individually and collectively wrote as they did in my behalf and condemned the falsehood of my enemies justly, and in accordance with the truth? Who that has observed such proceedings as these will deny that Valens and Ursacius had good reason to condemn themselves, and to write as they did, to accuse themselves when they repented, choosing rather to suffer shame for a short time, than to undergo the punishment of false accusers for ever and ever?  89.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:249
verses.text: Wherefore also my blessed fellow-ministers, acting justly and according to the laws of the Church, while certain affirmed that my case was doubtful, and endeavoured to compel them to annul the sentence which was passed in my favour, have now endured all manner of sufferings, and have chosen rather to be banished than to see the judgment of so many Bishops reversed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:250
verses.text: Now if those genuine Bishops had withstood by words only those who plotted against me, and wished to undo all that had been done in my behalf; or if they had been ordinary men, and not the Bishops of illustrious cities, and the heads of great Churches, there would have been room to suspect that in this instance they too had acted contentiously and in order to gratify me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:251
verses.text: But when they not only endeavoured to convince by argument, but also endured banishment, and one of them is Liberius, Bishop of Rome, (for although he did not endure to the end the sufferings of banishment, yet he remained in his exile for two years, being aware of conspiracy formed against us), and since there is also the great Hosius, together with the Bishops of Italy, and of Gaul, and others from Spain, and from Egypt, and Libya, and all those from Pentapolis (for although for a little while, through fear of the threats of Constantius, he seemed not to resist them yet the great violence and tyrannical power exercised by Constantius, and the many insults and stripes inflicted upon him, proved that it was not because he gave up my cause, but through the weakness of old age, being unable to bear the stripes, that he yielded to them for a season), therefore I say, it is altogether right that all, as being fully convinced, should hate and abominate the injustice and the violence which they have used towards me; especially as it is well known that I have suffered these things on account of nothing else but the Arian impiety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:252
Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:253
verses.text: Now if anyone wishes to become acquainted with my case, and the falsehood of Eusebius and his fellows, let him read what has been written in my behalf, and let him hear the witnesses, not one, or two, or three, but that great number of Bishops; and again let him attend to the witnesses of these proceedings, Liberius and Hosius, and their fellows, who when they saw the attempts made against us, chose rather to endure all manner of sufferings than to give up the truth, and the judgment which had been pronounced in our favour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:254
verses.text: And this they did with an honourable and righteous intention, for what they suffered proves to what straits the other Bishops were reduced.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:255
verses.text: And they are memorials and records against the Arian heresy, and the wickedness of false accusers, and afford a pattern and model for those who come after, to contend for the truth unto death, and to abominate the Arian heresy which fights against Christ, and is a forerunner of Antichrist, and not to believe those who attempt to speak against me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Defence Against the Arians II 2:256
verses.text: For the defence put forth, and the sentence given, by so many Bishops of high character, are a trustworthy and sufficient testimony in our behalf.
